Questions about the St. Helens School District HS Bond?

How will this bond affect my taxes?
The total amount of the High School Bond request would be $55 million dollars and represent an increase of $0.94 per $1,000 of assessed value. The Board of Directors has directed the district to delay assessment of this increase due to current economic uncertainty. Taxpayers would not see this tax increase until 2022.

How do I know bond funds would be spent on these projects?
If the measure passes, funds could only be used for projects approved by voters. Additionally, an independent citizen-led Bond Oversight Committee would be established to oversee the use of bond funds and regular, independent audits will be conducted.

Nominations are now being accepted for the Oregon Teacher of the Year program. With origins in 1955, the Oregon Teacher of the Year program celebrates exemplary educators throughout the state. Outstanding teachers will be honored in up to 19 Education Service District regions in Oregon, and will then be entered to win the recognition of 2021 Oregon Teacher of the Year.

Candidates for Oregon Teacher of the Year should be exceptionally dedicated, knowledgeable, and skilled licensed public school educators in grades PreK-12 (administrative responsibilities should be of secondary consideration). The candidate should be planning to continue in an active teaching status.

You can nominate through the district website at www.sthelens.k12.or.us or at www.oregonteacheroftheyear.org

Deadline to nominate is January 31, 2020.

Mrs. Wentworth is not only an exceptional teacher, but she is also an amazing human being with a huge heart! My son had the honor of having her in first grade a few years ago. She still takes the time to check in with him daily and treats him as she would any of her current students. She is known to go over and beyond for her students and invests so much of her heart and time into each and every one of her kids.

Her heartfelt approach with her students is contagious. She has always taken the time to truly see the inner needs of each one of her students and works with each one individually to make sure they are succeeding to their fullest potential.

Her classroom is a place where kids can feel safe and want to learn. She always makes sure her student's basic needs are met first, that their stomachs are full, they are well-rested, they feel emotionally safe and that they feel they are in a trusted safe place before diving into learning which is crucial for any successful classroom.

Mrs. Wentworth is simply amazing!

St. Helens Middle School Zero Robotics students had a great experience visiting the Oregon State University campus for Field Day. Joined by other teams from around the state, the St. Helens Vortex acted out satellite movements to help conceptualize their programming goals.

After the field activities, students were treated with the opportunity to hear from Astronomer-in-Residence and Oregon's NASA representative, Dr. Randall Milstein who guided students in safely examining the sun using a solar telescope.

Students finished the day with an exciting campus tour guided by former Oregon State defensive end Dorian Smith who is in his fourth year on the coaching staff and works on campus as a graduate assistant. The St. Helens Zero Robotics team has been learning C++ language to program a small satellite called a SPHERE inside the International Space Station.

It's been two years since the St. Helens School District finalized its strategic plan and set out on a new mission of Strengthening Community through Exceptional Schools to achieve a vision for the district of Exceptionally Educated Students by the Most Skilled and Highly Compassionate Staff. As part of developing that plan, the district engaged in listening sessions during which participants reflected on specific questions to build a plan that was reflective of our community's wants and needs. In the spirit of continued responsiveness and transparency, the St. Helens School District has scheduled four additional listening sessions with Superintendent Stockwell. The listening sessions are designed to be open-ended without an agenda so that the community may provide feedback about what is going well in the district and what are challenges to overcome.

We hope that you are able to join us at Columbia City Elementary for the second of four district listening sessions.

Columbia City Elementary, Library

Did you know there’s a really close connection between school attendance and student success? Students who are chronically absent (that means they miss 10 percent of the year for excused or unexcused reasons) are much more likely to struggle in school and even have more trouble graduating. It makes sense because every day builds on the one before, making it easy to fall behind.

Get tips on how to improve your child’s attendance at every-day-matters.org.

St. Helens School District and St. Helens Les Schwab have partnered together to implement the Tire Less Teacher Award.

Not only can teachers be the recipients of this award, but any staff member from any St. Helens school can be nominated and receive this award.

This weekly award will be given out every Friday starting in November and be featured in the St. Helens School District Good News Editions.

Les Schwab has graciously supplied the awards and will provide each recipient with a gift card.

We started this program off today at St. Helens High School and presented the first ever Les Schwab Tire Less Teacher award to Diana Peterson.

Congratulations, Diana!
